## shape, size, fill, color, and transparency - Exercise 9

R has 25 built in shapes that are identified by numbers.

Some are similar: 0, 15, and 22 are all squares, but interact differently with
`color` and `fill` aesthetics.

Hollow shapes have a border determined by `color`, solid shapes (15-18) are
filled with `color`, an the filled shapes (21-24) have `color` border and `fill`
inside.

![](../img/ggplot2/ggplot-shapes.png)

---

Get a diamonds subset.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
diamonds_subset <- sample_n(diamonds, 1000)
```
:::


---

Note that aesthetics can also be defined *within* a geom.

This is useful if you use two different geoms that share an aesthetic.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price
  )
) +
  geom_point(
    aes(
      fill = cut,
      size = depth
    ),
    alpha = 0.8,
    shape = 24,
    color = "white"
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


## Position adjustments - Exercise 10

Position adjustments determine how to arrange geoms that would otherwise occupy the same space.

![](../img/ggplot2/ggplot-position.png)

---

A stacked bar chart.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = cut,
    fill = clarity
  )
) +
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Dodged bars are easier to read (proportions are clearer)


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = cut,
    fill = clarity
  )
) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


## Coordinate and Scale Functions - Exercise 11

* The coordinate system determines how the x and y aesthetics combine to position elements in the plot. The default coordinate system is Cartesian (`coord_cartesian()`), which can be tweaked with `coord_map()`, `coord_fixed()`, `coord_flip()`, and `coord_trans()`, or completely replaced with `coord_polar()`.

* Scales control the details of how data values are translated to visual properties. There are 20+ scale functions. We will look at one; the ggplot2 cheatsheet is your friend for the rest.

---

Logarithmic axes - 1

Note the difference between axis labels in these two examples.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(carat, price)
) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_trans(x = "log10")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: `coord_trans()` was deprecated in ggplot2 4.0.0.
ℹ Please use `coord_transform()` instead.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Logarithmic axes - 2


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(carat, price)
) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Flipping coordinate system (swapping `x` and `y`)


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(x = cut)
) +
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Now flip the axis.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="6"}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(x = cut)
) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Brief aside: ggplot can handle on-the-fly data transformations.

Here we log-transform carat and convert USD to CAD.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(
    x = log10(carat),
    y = price * 1.32
  )
) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


## Zooming into a plot - Exercise 12

---

We might want to change the limits of x or y axes to zoom in.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(carat, price)
) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  xlim(0, 2) +
  ylim(0, 5000)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Removed 261 rows containing missing values or values
outside the scale range (`geom_point()`).
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


## Faceting to plot subsets of data into separate panels - Exercise 13

"Facets" are a powerful tool to subdivide a plot based on the values of one or more discrete variables.

![](../img/ggplot2/ggplot-facet.png)

---

A density plot we've seen before.

**Which variables can we use to subdivide the data?**


::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    fill = cut
  )
) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.8)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Faceted by `cut`


::: {.cell output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="12-15"}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = log(price),
  )
) +
  geom_density(
    fill = "blue",
    color = "blue",
    alpha = 0.2
  ) +
  facet_wrap(
    ~cut,
    nrow = 1
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

---

Let's also use `facet_grid()` to facet by two variables.

Faceted by `clarity` and `cut`.


::: {.cell output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="12-14"}
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = log(price)
  )
) +
  geom_density(
    fill = "blue",
    color = "blue",
    alpha = 0.2
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    clarity ~ cut
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Scatter plot with facets.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
#|
#| fig.alt: "Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN"
ggplot(
  diamonds,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price,
    color = cut
  )
) +
  geom_point(alpha = .05) +
  facet_wrap(
    ~cut,
    nrow = 1
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Themes - Exercise 14

Themes can significantly affect the appearance of your plot. Thanksfully, there are a lot to choose from.

![](../img/ggplot2/ggplot-themes.png)

---

Scatter plot with default theme.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price,
    color = cut
  )
) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Change the theme with `theme_bw()`.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="10"}
ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price,
    color = cut
  )
) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +
  theme_bw()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

**My go-to is `cowplot::theme_cowplot()`.**

It implements much of the advice in the "Dataviz" book, i.e.. YOUR LABELS ARE TOO
SMALL.


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="10"}
ggplot(
  data = diamonds_subset,
  mapping = aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price,
    color = cut
  )
) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +
  theme_cowplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

We're not going to cover it, but you can also customize pre-existing themes.

## Labels & Legends - Exercise 15

![](../img/ggplot2/ggplot-labels-legends.png)

---

Use `labs()` to add / change plot labels.


::: {.cell output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="10-17"}
ggplot(
  data = diamonds,
  mapping = aes(
    x = fct_reorder(cut, log(price)),
    y = log(price)
  )
) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +
  labs(
    x = "Cut",
    y = "Price (log)",
    color = "Cut",
    title = "Distribution of diamond prices by cut",
    subtitle = "If you liked it then you shoulda put a ring on it",
    caption = "Source: diamonds dataset from ggplot2"
  ) +
  theme_cowplot()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Ignoring unknown labels:
• colour : "Cut"
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


# *Additional points*

## How to add a line to a plot? (Exercise 16)


::: {.cell output-location='column-fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
p <- ggplot(
  diamonds_subset,
  aes(
    x = carat,
    y = price,
    color = cut
  )
) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +
  theme_cowplot()

p + geom_line()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

Also try:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 5000))
p + geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 2))
p + geom_smooth(method = lm)
p + geom_abline(aes(intercept = 0.5, slope = 5000))
```
:::


## How to combine multiple plots into a figure? (Exercise 17)


::: {.cell output-location='fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# `plot_grid()` is from `cowplot`
plot_grid(
  p,
  p,
  p,
  p,
  labels = c(
    "A",
    "B",
    "C",
    "D"
  ),
  nrow = 2
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){fig-alt='Description of the plot - PLEASE FILL IN' width=960}
:::
:::


---

We have 4 legends - can they be condensed?

Yes, but it is not exactly straightforward.

**need to scroll below**


::: {.cell output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# fetch the legend for `p1`
legend <- get_legend(
  p + theme(legend.position = "bottom")
)

p <- p + theme(legend.position = "none")

# first `plot_grid` builds the panels
panels <- plot_grid(
  p,
  p,
  p,
  p,
  labels = c(
    "A",
    "B",
    "C",
    "D"
  ),
  nrow = 2
)

# second `plot_grid` adds the legend to the panels
plot_grid(
  panels,
  legend,
  ncol = 1,
  rel_heights = c(1, .1)
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](slides-05_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Saving plots (Exercise 18)

Saves last plot as 5' x 5' file named "plot_final.png" in working directory.

Matches file type to file extension.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggsave(here("img/plot_final.png"), width = 5, height = 5)
```
:::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
